name: Naan
history: Naan is a popular Indian leavened flatbread with Persian origins. It became a staple in the Indian subcontinent with the arrival of the Mughals and is traditionally cooked in a tandoor or clay oven.
description: Naan is a soft and fluffy flatbread, typically made with wheat flour and yogurt, and leavened with yeast or baking powder. It's often brushed with butter or ghee and can include flavors like garlic or herbs.

instructions.title: Prepare the Dough
instructions.description: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water. Let it sit for 10 minutes until frothy. In a mixing bowl, combine flour, salt, baking powder, yogurt, and oil. Add the yeast mixture and knead into a soft dough. Cover and let it rest for 1-2 hours.

instructions.title: Roll the Naan
instructions.description: Divide the dough into small balls. Roll each ball into an oval shape. Optionally, press minced garlic into the dough.

instructions.title: Cook the Naan
instructions.description: Heat a tawa or skillet. Place the rolled naan on it and cook until bubbles appear. Flip and cook the other side until brown spots appear. Brush with butter or ghee.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Garnish with chopped cilantro if desired. Serve hot with curries, dal, or as a standalone snack.

tips: Ensure the water is warm, not hot, to activate the yeast properly.
The dough should be soft and pliable for the best texture.
variations: Add herbs like dried fenugreek leaves (kasuri methi) for additional flavor.
Stuff with cheese or spiced potato filling for a different twist.

storage.shelfLife: Best consumed fresh but can be stored in an airtight container for up to 24 hours.
storage.instructions: Reheat on a skillet before serving if stored.

reheatingInstructions: Reheat on a hot skillet or tawa until warm and soft.
presentationTips: Serve in a basket lined with a cloth to keep the naan warm.
Pair with a variety of dips and side dishes for a complete meal.
